document.title: Subgraphs
document.text: Let G=(V,E) be a graph and V' be a subset of V. Using the notation in Jungnickel 2007, by E|V' we denote the set of all edges e \in E(G) that have both vertices in V'. The resulting graph G'=(V',E|V') is the induced subgraph of G on V' and it will be denoted as G|V'.
Each graph of the form G'=(V',E') where V' \subset V and E' \subseteq E|V' is said to be a subgraph of G.
A subgraph of the same order of the original graph, i.e. when V'=V, is a spanning subgraph.

A k-factor is a k-regular spanning subgraph. When the edge set of a graph is divided into k-factors, such a decomposition is called a k-factorization of the graph. A 1-factorization, or factorization for short, can exist only if G has an even number of vertices and it is also called a resolution. Factorizations of K_{2n} can be interpreted as schedules for tournaments of 2n teams and always exist Jungnickel 2007.

DYAD: A subgraph with 2 nodes + Undirected graphs: 2 dyadic states + Directed graphs: 3 isomorphic classes (null dyad, asymmetric dyad, and mutual/reciprocal dyad
TRIAD: A subgraph with 3 nodes + Undirected graphs: 4 triadic states (0-3 links) e.g. forbidden triad (2 links), unlikely with strong ties Granovetter 1973

note.title: Graph isomorphism
note.text: When are two graphs considered different? Basically, when they do not have the same structure, which leads as to the concept of graph isomorphism.

Two graphs G = (V(G),E(G)) and H = (V(H),E(H)) are called isomorphic if there is a bijective function \phi: V(G) \rightarrow V(H) such that (u, v) \in E(G) if and only if (\phi(u), \phi(v)) \in E(H) for all u, v \in V(G).
The isomorphisms of a graph G to itself are called automorphisms.

When two graphs G and H are isomorphic, they have the same number of nodes (i.e. the same order), the same number of links (i.e. the same size), and the degrees of the vertices of G are the same as the degrees of the vertices of H.
